metrics package¶

Submodules¶

metrics.forecasting_metrics module¶

metrics.forecasting_metrics.horizon_metric(sample_predictions, y_true, metric_func)¶
Parameters

  • sample_predictions – (n_forecast_points, forecast_horizon)

  • y_true – (n_forecast_points + forecast_horizon)

  • metric_func –

Returns

metric for each step in the horizon i.e. (forecast_horizon) sized array

metrics.forecasting_metrics.step_forecast_metrics(forecasts, true_values, metric)¶
Parameters

  • forecasts – array like of shape (n_forecast_points, horizon_length)

  • true_values – array like of shape (n_forecast_points + horizon_length) or same shape as :forecasts

  • metric – func with two same sized 1D arrays arguments (forecasts, true_forecast_values) for evaluating forecasts

Returns

metric for each forecast point (n_forecast_points)

metrics.general module¶

metrics.general.calculate_metric_dict(predictions, true_values, metrics)¶

Calculates each given metric for given predictions and their true values.

Use case: in case of running multiple different experiments at the top of the file you can easily define your set of metrics and easily store them. If at a later point you decide to change your metrics you need only change a single dict

Parameters

  • predictions –

  • true_values –

  • metrics – dict with key-value pairs metric name-metric func that you want calculated. Each metric func should receive parameters (predictions, true_values)
